description:
A bunch of Marvel-themed Magic: The Gathering Secret Lairs were unveiled at a New York Comic Con panel on October 18. There are five Secret Lairs in total, each one based around a particular hero. Each contains five cards: a couple of thematic reprints, one or two renamed spells and - most interesting of all - a unique legendary creature depicting the character.

Continue reading MTG: Wolverine, Iron Man, and Storm revealed for Marvel crossover
MORE FROM WARGAMER:
title: MTG: Wolverine, Iron Man, and Storm revealed for Marvel crossover

description:
In a result that left me unsurprised, but genuinely delighted, Modiphius’ Terry Pratchett Discworld RPG has made a killing on Kickstarter, racking up nearly $1.4 million (£1 million), more than ten times its initial funding goal, in only three days. I’m unspeakably excited to play - but I confess I was a little disappointed to see no miniatures among the pile of enticing extra knick-knacks offered in the crowdfunder.

Continue reading Five Discworld RPG minis I’m painting to get in the mood
MORE FROM WARGAMER:
title: Five Discworld RPG minis I’m painting to get in the mood

description:
Modrons are one of the best - and most easily overlooked - monster subtype in the whole of the DnD Monster Manual. Originating in the lawful neutral plane of Mechanus, they are entities of perfect order, but their rigid adherence to rules can make them hilarious, chaotic, and downright dangerous - a perfect addition to any DnD campaign.

Continue reading Dungeons and Dragons: Why your campaign needs more Modrons
MORE FROM WARGAMER: DnD 2024 Player's Handbook review,
title: Dungeons and Dragons: Why your campaign needs more Modrons

description:
Many DMs strive for perfect balance in a Dungeons and Dragons encounter. You’d think, then, that the best fights in D&D are those where the opponents are equally matched. This isn’t always the case. Sometimes, the unexpected landslide victories are the ones that go down in history. D&D, like life, can often throw a spanner in the works. Or, in the case of my campaign, a magical cabbage.

Continue reading Dungeons and Dragons: how a magical cabbage almost derailed my campaign
MORE FROM WARGAMER:
title: Dungeons and Dragons: how a magical cabbage almost derailed my campaign

description:
The Inquisition Player’s Guide for Warhammer 40k RPG Imperium Maledictum went up for pre-order on Thursday, and thanks to an early sample from Cubicle 7 I've had access to it for a few days. I'm surprised and pleased by how useful the contents will be for any kind of campaign, not just ones focused on the Inquisition - and Rogue Traders are particularly well served.

Continue reading Warhammer 40k’s new tabletop RPG book is secretly great for Rogue Trader
MO
title: Warhammer 40k’s new tabletop RPG book is secretly great for Rogue Trader

description:
Sometimes, I simply don’t have time or space for a big board game. As I approach my thirties, it’s only getting harder to get my friends around a table for an eight-hour strategy session. That’s where a game like Scout comes in. This pint-sized circus game may be smaller than a banana, but it’s made a big impact on my gaming habits. I can and do bring Scout everywhere, and it helps me squeeze short gaming sessions in on the regular.

Continue reading Scout board game review - the card game I carry everywhere
MORE FROM WARGAMER: Best boa
title: Scout board game review - the card game I carry everywhere

description:
The Magic: The Gathering card Séance Board has seen a sudden price spike. This card, found in the Valgavoth precon deck, was very cheap in the first few weeks after Duskmourn released, valued at just $1. But it’s been spiking for the last seven days, jumping up by a whopping 444%.

Continue reading Cheap Duskmourn MTG card sees 450% price spike
MORE FROM WARGAMER: All MTG sets in order, Upcoming MTG re
title: Cheap Duskmourn MTG card sees 450% price spike

description:
It’s no secret that building a Warhammer 40k army is very expensive, particularly a full 2,000 point tournament list. But if you’ve got time, a creative eye, and a big enough bits box, it’s possible to bring that total down substantially by converting, kit-bashing, and scratch-building everything. Ork player Aaron Lee Yaeger has set the bar low: his growing Ork force has so far cost just $10.33.

Continue reading Warhammer 40k: how to make a full 2,000 point army for under $20

title: Warhammer 40k: how to make a full 2,000 point army for under $20
